review.title: Wavelet-Based Semantic Features for Hyperspectral Signature Discrimination
review.abstract: Hyperspectral signature classification is a quantitative analysis approach for hyperspectral imagery which performs detection and classification of the constituent materials at the pixel level in the scene. The classification procedure can be operated directly on hyperspectral data or performed by using some features extracted from the corresponding hyperspectral signatures containing information like the signature's energy or shape. In this paper, we describe a technique that applies non-homogeneous hidden Markov chain (NHMC) models to hyperspectral signature classification. The basic idea is to use statistical models (such as NHMC) to characterize wavelet coefficients which capture the spectrum semantics (i.e., structural information) at multiple levels. Experimental results show that the approach based on NHMC models can outperform existing approaches relevant in classification tasks.

sections.heading: B. Wavelet Analysis
sections.text: The waveform of a signal provides a multi-scale analysis of the signal content that effectively encodes the locations and scales on which the signal structure is present in a compact manner [16]. To date, several hyspectral classification methods based on wave transformation have been proposed, and most of these classification approaches (e.g. [8], [17], [18]) use dyadic / decimalized wave transformation (DWT) as a pre-processing step. Compared to UWT, DWT provides a more precise representation because it minimizes the amount of redundancy in the coefficients. However, the compromise for such redundancy is that UWT provides maximum flexibility in the choice of scales and offsets used in multi-scale analysis, which allows easy characterization of the spectral structure at each spectral bandwidth.

This property motivates the use of a zero-mean-Gaussian mixing model (GMM) with two Gaussian components to capture the compression characteristics, "characterizing a large number of Gaussian coefficients."

sections.heading: E. Wavelet-based Spectral Matching
sections.text: Many hyperspectral signature classification approaches have been proposed in the literature, a subset of which includes wavelength series analysis [6], [7], [22], [23]. In this paper, we review two approaches that are particularly close to our proposed method, which are used for comparison in our numerical experiments. Since our focus in this paper is on the hyperspectral classification of individual pixels, we limit our comparison to methods that rely exclusively on the spectrum of a particular pixel or on properties derived from the spectra of the pixel. More specifically, we do not compare with other methods that use additional information (e.g. spatial information for an HSI) or that rely on prior knowledge of the location of semantic information normally obtained by an expert. sections.heading: III. NHMC-BASED FEATURE EXTRACTION AND CLASSIFICATION
sections.text: In this section, we present a feature extraction scheme for hyperspectral signatures that uses a Markov model for the wavelet coefficients of the signature. In a UWT, a wavelet analysis is used to gather information about the fluctuations of the spectra. State labels extracted from the Markov model represent the semantic information relevant for hyperspectral signal processing.

sections.heading: A. Multi-State Hidden Markov Chain Model
sections.text: In our system, we choose to use the NHMC model described in section II-D, which is applied to the UWT across the wavelength spectrum. We select the hair wavelength system because of its special shape, which makes the size of the wavelength coefficient proportional to the inclination of the spectra across the wavelength support. Furthermore, the signs of these coefficients are indicative of the inclination orientation (increasing or decreasing for negative or positive). In contrast to the previous work [11], we design our NHMC as characteristics of the k-state GMM for the wavelength coefficient. We increase the number of states from 2 to k > 2, because a two-state mean GMM makes an excessively rough distinction between sharper absorption bands (fluctuations) and flatter regions in a hyperspectral signature, which are normally assigned to large or small states.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed the design of a feature extraction scheme for hyperspectral signatures that preserves the semantic information used by practitioners in signature discrimination (i.e., the location of the distinction between fluctuations and discontinuities).However, our approach is automated by the use of statistical models of wave motion that concisely capture the location and size of fluctuations in the observed spectra. Furthermore, the 20er model allows spectra to be segmented into informative and non-informative portions. The success of statistical modeling is largely dependent on the availability of a large-scale database for training with representative examples observed by the sensor system.
